questions.question:
Question 1: Which of the following structures do not pass through both greater and lesser sciatic 
foramens?
questions.explanation:
The tendon of the obturator internus muscle passes only through the lesser sciatic foramen. Structures passing through both the greater and lesser sciatic foramen: 1115 
Sold by @itachibot • Pudendal nerve • Internal pudendal vessels • Nerve to obturator internus.

questions.question:
Question 2: All of the following structures are derived from the aponeurosis of the external oblique 
muscle except:
questions.explanation:
Linea semilunaris is derived from the aponeurosis of the internal oblique muscle. Pectineal ligament, inguinal ligament and lacunar ligament are derived from the external oblique 
aponeurosis.

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following muscles does not form the floor of the femoral triangle?
questions.explanation:
Psoas major forms the floor of the femoral triangle, not psoas minor. The femoral triangle is an intermuscular space in the anteromedial aspect of the thigh. Its 
boundaries are: • Lateral boundary is formed by the medial margin of sartorius • Medial boundary is formed by the medial margin of adductor longus. • Floor of the femoral triangle from lateral to medial is formed by: • Iliacus • Psoas major • Pectineus • Adductor longus 1116 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following forms the lateral boundary of the femoral triangle?
questions.explanation: The lateral boundary of the femoral triangle is formed by the medial margin of the sartorius. Its medial boundary is formed by the medial margin of adductor longus.

questions.question:
Question 5: A resident was inserting a central venous line through the femoral vein. He accidentally 
injured the structure medial to the femoral vein, within the femoral sheath. Which structure 
is likely to be injured?
questions.explanation:
The lymphatic vessels lie medial to the femoral vein and are likely to be injured in this case. Femoral sheath is the funnel-shaped prolongation of the fascia which contains femoral vessels. 
Anteriorly it is made of transversalis fascia and posteriorly it is made of fascia iliaca. It is divided into three compartments: • The lateral compartment contains femoral artery • The intermediate compartment contains femoral vein • The medial compartment which is termed as femoral canal contains: • Lymphatic vessels • Areolar tissue • Lymph node of Cloquet. The empty space in the femoral canal allows distension of the adjacent femoral vein, so it can cope 
with increased venous return, or increased intra-abdominal pressure.

questions.question:
Question 6: A patient underwent an aortic valve replacement surgery through the femoral artery. 
Post-operatively, he complaints of groin pain radiating down the anteromedial thigh. Which 
of the following is true regarding the nerve injured?

options.a: It lies medial to the femoral artery
options.b: It is not a content of the femoral sheath
options.c: The nerve injured is the sciatic nerve
options.d: It arises from the anterior cords of the lumbar plexus

questions.explanation:
The nerve injured is the femoral nerve. Femoral nerve is not a content of the femoral sheath. 1117 
Sold by @itachibot Femoral sheath forms a fascial compartment which is further divided into 3 compartments by the 
intervening septae: • The lateral compartment contains femoral artery • The intermediate compartment contains femoral vein • The medial compartment which is termed as femoral canal contains • Lymphatic vessels • Areolar tissue • Lymph node of cloquet The empty space in the femoral canal allows distension of the adjacent femoral vein, so it can cope 
with increased venous return, or increased intra-abdominal pressure. Option A - Femoral nerve lies lateral to the femoral artery Option C - Sciatic nerve injury may occur after misplaced intramuscular injection in the gluteal 
region. It leads to loss of sensation at the outer side of ankle and heel and foot drop.

questions.question:
Question 7: A middle aged man is found to have a globular swelling below and lateral to the pubic 
tubercle. A diagnosis of femoral hernia is made. Which structure forms the posterior border 
of the ring the hernia passes through?
questions.explanation:
Femoral hernia will pass through the femoral ring proximally. The posterior border of the femoral 
ring is formed by the pectineal ligament. Relations of the femoral ring: • Anterior border by the inguinal ligament • Posterior border by the • Pectineal ligament • Superior ramus of the pubic bone • Pectineus muscle 1118 
Sold by @itachibot • Medial border by the lacunar ligament • Lateral border by the femoral vein

questions.question:
Question 8: 1111 
Sold by @itachibot An adolescent is crossing the road while playing loud music on his headphones. He is struck 
by a car and rushed to the emergency room. The physicians notice a distal femur fracture 
with vascular compromise. Intraoperatively, the femoral vessels are found to be injured at the 
adductor hiatus. Which muscle is likely to be involved in this injury ?
questions.explanation:
In the given scenario, femoral vessels are injured at the adductor hiatus. The adductor hiatus is an 
opening in the tendon of the adductor magnus. Hence, the muscle likely to be injured is the 
adductor magnus. Clinical relevance: The adductor part of the adductor magnus attaches to the distal femur. Distal 
femur fractures may cause femoral artery injury and impairment of the blood supply to the lower 
leg. 1119 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 9: The hunter's canal lies beneath which muscle?
questions.explanation:
The hunter’s canal lies beneath the sartorius muscle. It is also referred to as the subsartorial canal 
or adductor canal. The hunter’s canal is a triangular intermuscular tunnel occupying the lower two-thirds of the 
medial aspect of the thigh.

questions.question:
Question 10: A 40 year old basketball player who sustained an ACL tear is being posted for ACL 
reconstruction surgery. The anesthetist plans an adductor canal block for the procedure. 
Which of the following structures is he least likely to encounter while giving the block ?
questions.explanation:
The femoral nerve is least likely to be encountered while giving an adductor canal block. Adductor 
canal does not contain the femoral nerve. However, it contains its branches - the saphenous and 
and nerve to vastus medialis. Contents of the adductor canal: • Saphenous nerve (largest cutaneous branch of the femoral nerve) • Nerve to vastus medialis • Femoral artery • Descending genicular artery • Femoral vein • Deep lymphatic vessels

questions.question:
Question 11: Which of the following is the correct relationship with regards to the saphenous nerve in the 
adductor canal?
questions.explanation: The saphenous nerve is anterior to the femoral artery in the adductor canal.

questions.question:
Question 12: A patient presents with a chronic ulcer in the popliteal fossa. The surgeon plans to make a 
musculocutaneous flap using a muscle from the superolateral boundary of the fossa. Which 
muscle is to be used for the flap?
questions.explanation:
The surgeon plans to use the biceps femoris muscle for the flap. Biceps femoris forms the superolateral border of the popliteal fossa. Popliteal fossa is a diamond-shaped region present posterior to the knee. 1120 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 13: Which of the following is not a content of the popliteal fossa?
questions.explanation:
The lateral femoral cutaneous nerve is not a content of the popliteal fossa. It arises from the 
ventral rami of L2 and L3, and ends up supplying the skin of anterolateral thigh. Contents of Popliteal fossa: • Popliteal artery and its branches • Popliteal vein and its tributaries • Tibial nerve • Common fibular (Peroneal) nerve • Short saphenous vein • Posterior femoral cutaneous nerve • Articular branch of the obturator nerve • Medial and Lateral sural cutaneous nerve • Lymph nodes • Fat • Bursae 1121 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 14: Which of the following bones form the anterior pillar of the lateral longitudinal arch of the 
foot?

options.a: Talus, navicular, 3 cuneiform and 1st, 2nd and 3rd metatarsal

questions.explanation:
The anterior pillar of the lateral longitudinal arch of the foot is formed by 4th and 5th metatarsals. 1122 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 15: The keystone of the medial longitudinal arch is formed by  
.
questions.explanation: The keystone (summit) of the medial longitudinal arch is formed by the talus.

questions.question:
Question 16: A 42-year-old man had trauma to the right foot, following which he complained of difficulty 
in walking. Examination showed collapse of the medial longitudinal arch. Injury to all of the 
following structures may cause the given condition except:
questions.explanation:
Peroneus longus muscle maintains the lateral longitudinal arch and not the medial arch. The muscles, tendons, and aponeurosis that maintain the longitudinal arches of the foot are of 
two types: • Slings: These structures help to maintain the arch by suspending the arch from above. 1123 
Sold by @itachibot • Tie beams (bowstrings): These are present between the anterior and posterior pillars and help 
maintain the arch by preventing the separation of the pillars.

questions.question:
Question 17: Which of the following structures does not pass deep to the superior extensor retinacula of 
foot?
questions.explanation:
The tendon of tibialis posterior does not pass deep to the superior extensor retinacula of the foot. The following are the structures passing deep to the superior and inferior extensor retinacula: • Tibialis anterior tendon • Extensor hallucis longus tendon • Deep peroneal nerve • Extensor digitorum longus tendon • Peroneus tertius tendon The anterior tibial vessels pass deep to the superior extensor retinaculum, while the dorsalis pedis 
vessels pass deep to the inferior extensor retinaculum. Note: The tendon of tibialis posterior passes deep to the flexor retinaculum of the foot

questions.question: Question 18: Which of the following statements is false about the inferior extensor retinaculum of the foot?

options.a: The upper band is attached to the lower end of the fibula
options.c: The lower band is attached to the deep fascia of sole
options.d: Laterally it is attached to calcaneum

questions.explanation:
Upper band is attached to medial malleolus of the tibia and not fibula. Inferior extensor retinaculum: • It is a Y-shaped band lying anterior to the ankle joint. • The stem of the Y is at the lateral end and is attached to the upper surface of the calcaneus. 1124 
Sold by @itachibot • The limbs of the Y are at the medial end. The proximal limb attaches to the medial malleolus 
and the distal limb blends with the plantar aponeurosis. Structures passing deep to retinaculum are: • Peroneus tertius • Extensor digitorum longus • Extensor hallucis longus • Tibialis anterior • Anterior tibial vessels • Dorsalis pedis artery • Deep peroneal nerve

questions.question:
Question 19: Which of the following is the most medial structure passing through the canals in the flexor 
retinaculum of the foot? 1114 
Sold by @itachibot

options.b: Thoracic curve develops when the infant starts walking.

questions.explanation:
Tibialis posterior tendon is the most medial structure passing through the canals in the flexor 
retinaculum of the foot. The flexor retinaculum of the foot converts grooves on the tibia and calcaneus into canals for the 
tendons. The structures passing through canals formed by flexor retinaculum are as follows: (from 
medial to lateral) • Tendons of tibialis posterior • Flexor digitorum longus • The posterior tibial vessels • The tibial nerve • The tendon of flexor hallucis longus 1125 
Sold by @itachibot 1126 
Sold by @itachibot Vertebral Column
